title: Typefaces used in magazine design in the 60's
content:
Hi,  
Trying to find out some typefaces here, that were used in magazine design  
from around the 60's.

Cheers!

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [type\_1.gif](http://web.archive.org/web/20150127232247/http:/typophile.com/files/type_1.gif) | 114.97 KB |
| [type\_2.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150127232247/http:/typophile.com/files/type_2_0.jpg) | 150.41 KB |
author: apparatus™

comments.content:
Sorry Tiffany... it's not [Futura Black](http://web.archive.org/web/20150127232247/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/futura-black-sb/regular/testdrive.html?s=BLICK&p=72) [.  
](http://web.archive.org/) [Futura XBold](http://web.archive.org/web/20150127232247/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/futura-sb/xbold/testdrive.html?s=BLICK&p=72)  
 [Futura XLight](http://web.archive.org/web/20150127232247/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/efscangraphic/futura-sh/xlight/testdrive.html?s=FOTO-ESSAY&p=60)

-------------------------------------------------  
Yes, I'm old, but I'm back in style!
If I recall correctly, Futura Black is a stencil-like typeface ... a style all by its own.
Freeeeeaaak! I meant Futura Extra Bold!
Yeah, Futura Black is like an adopted son or something. It looks so unlike the other weights.
